ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course provides students with a diverse selection of readings that broadens one's perspectives and helps to formulate different questions that one should ask while thinking about the history of medicine and public health. I would recommend students to take the course if they would like to have a solid grounding in the types of histories of medicine that are being written.

Course engaging with the history of health and medicine and America through close reading of range of secondary texts (rather than primary or historiographic). Topics ranged from midwifery and public health to mental health and smoking.
This is a seminar class in which you get to read a number of very interesting books and have a discussion with colleagues from various backgrounds.
Perhaps not to all public health students, but to those with a serious interest in history and especially historiography.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It provided the questions I needed to ask as I engage in my own research as well as the types of writings that can be done. Furthermore, it provided a general background of the history of medicine so that I know where and what to look at in the future.
